comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] No, I don’t think he will be a donor. Although to be fair to Mr Laws, aesthetics were not high on his or the nation’s agenda in 1944. The NSW Department of Main Roads was heavily involved in the war effort. From 1940 onwards the Department built roads, bridges, air fields and any infrastructure the Federal government asked for; in the Northern Territory, Queensland, Norfolk, Island and New Caledonia. We will feature some of the records this work left behind on the War and Australia web page in the coming months. You might be interested in another example of Mr Laws’ writing style. In February 1942 he was busy surveying the Northern Territory for bridge sites. He wanted to return to Darwin on 21 February 1942 but because of the bombing by the Japanese he ended up travelling from Larramar [Larrimah] to Alice Springs with a number of evacuees from Darwin. He comments on the lack of information available to him and the uncomfortable journey to Alice Springs during which everything of value was either broken or stolen www.records.nsw.gov.au/state-archives/research-topics/war... Jenny
